div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.– Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum.

ADVERTISEMENTS.– P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20, every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news columns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.) 36-4

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.

div.head: THE SITUATION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: This morning's telegrams are not by any means of a reassuring nature, but, on the contrary, tend to show that the revolutionary movement is spreading far and wide throughout the country. The evidences of insurrections in the provinces have been suppressed by the non-publication of the newspapers, but it is known that serious disturbances have broken out at Korno and Vilna. The revolutionary movement has spread among the 9,000 sailors of the Black Sea Fleet, to whom the fire at Sebastopol arsenal is due. Meanwhile the populace of Moscow are determined to emulate the example of St. Petersburg, and the workmen in the great factories are striking out of sympathy with their comrades.

The disaffection of the educated classes, as is seen by the action of the St. Petersburg Bar, is as dangerous a symptom as the conduct of the troops, who flatly refused to fire on the sailors at Sebastopol. But the most serious political symptom is the conduct of the Tsar. The one political institution in Russia is the Emperor or Autocrat. Only the Emperor can make laws; he alone has the executive and judicial power. Take away autocracy and Russian society falls into primeval chaos. To the masses of the people it is like taking the sun out of the sky. Autocracy is the necessary source of any legal change in Russian society. The attempt to start reform from any other source must inevitably produce a revolutionary condition, consisting of a prolonged warfare of each against all, and bringing in its train impoverishment and misery beyond even Russian precedent. But the Emperor has shown the world that he is utterly unable even in the present terrible crisis to rise superior to the inherent weakness of his naturally feeble character, and so he delegated the massacre of his subjects to the most reactionary of his kinsmen, while he took refuge in the recesses of his palace. Autocracy, as represented by the Tsar, has consequently now ceased to have any meaning to the people, and thus the fundamental basis of Russia's political life has been undermined.

On the other hand, the outlook is equally deplorable from the point of view of the people themselves, for the forces of reform in Russia possess neither the strength rela tively to the nation at large, nor the cohesion amongst themselves necessary for carrying out a general scheme of revolution. Poles, Finns, Jews, Dissenters, citizens, proprietors, peasants, are too hopelessly divided by racial and religious discord, by sheer distance, by interests, by their various fears of what the future may ultimately bring forth. They possess no means for executing concerted

An equally unknown factor is the attitude of the mighty host on the Sha-ho. It has been generally believed that the long period of inac tion which has elapsed since the last great battle has been more favorable to the Rus sians than to the Japanese, and that Kuropatkin is now far stronger in every way than he was when he fell back on his present position. But, if we may believe M. Dru, of the "Echo of Paris," that is not the fact. A month ago, as M. Dru is informed, Kuropatkin had only 175,000 infantry, and was short of mountain guns, his losses through sickness have been much higher than the public are aware, and his army is "literally melting away." To these facts must now be added the knowledge of the fall of Port Arthur, and the de pression which that knowledge must produce. Moreover it will be impossible to keep Kuropat kin's army in ignorance of the internal struggle going on at home. Strange rumours of massacres in St. Petersburg, of regiments refusing to fire on their own kith and kin, of the incendiary outbreak of the men of the Black Sea Fleet at Sebastopol, these and similar rumours, rendered still more alarming by exaggeration, must have a sinister effect on the morale of the army. The continuance of an unpopular war if the Government collapses is quite out of the question.

JERUSALEM, January 24. Monsignor L. Tavi, Latu Patriarch of der salem, lus died at the age of 74, from
The Bishop of Llandaff is dead. (Reuter.)

The Right Rev. Richard Lewis, D.D., Bishop of Llandatf, born in 1821, was educated at Worcester College, Oxford (B.A., 1843; M.A., 1846). He was instituted to the rectory of Lampeter-Velfry, Narberth, Pembrokeshire, in 1851, and was appointed Archdeacon of St. David's in 1875. In 1883 he was appointed Bishop of Llandaff in succession to Dr. Ollivant, and was consecrated to that Bee by the Archbishop of Canterbury in St. Paul's Cathedral, on April 25 of that year.

The fire broke out simultaneously in dif ferent parts directly after the signal was given to commence Work. The whole buildings were raparity involved. The tire was controlled by 1:30 pm The docks were saved. (Keuter.)

The "Standard learns from Kieff that the Are at Sevastopol was the outcome of a revolu tionary outbreak. Eight thousand sailors from the Black Sea Fleet and the troops were caned out. They retused, however, to hire.

THE BRINDISI MAIL will arrive at Alex- antra at 3 pm to-day and will be distributed at 7 pm.

NATIONAL BANK. At a meeting of the board of directors of the National Bank, held yesterday, at was decided to create 8 new branches in the provincial towns.
KAISERS BIRTHDAY Dr. Rucker-Jenisch will hold a reception at the Imperial German Agency, air, to morrow, on the occasion of the birthday of HIM. Emperor William II.
NEW De TORS. The Ministry of the Interior has authorised Dr. Nigoghos Simon Kludjean and Dr Artin Mardiros hernian to practise physicians in Egypt, and Ahmed Mehreya Pharmanst

A NEW NEWSPAPER has appeared at Cairo entitled "La Justice" and the editor is the notorions Armenian Leon Fehmy. This news- paper consists chiefly of personal attacks on various well known persons at Cairo.

RAIDON GAMBLING HELL. Another gambling house, situated in Kamel street, Cairo, and owned by a Greek, has been entered by the ponce. Baccarat was being played at the time. The material was, as usual, coutiscated.

TENANTS COMMISSION. The meeting of tenants summoned by the Alexandria Tenants' Commission for the 29th inst., has been indefinately postponed, owing to the preli minary labours of the commission not having been completed.

THE WHITE STAR LINER Canopic" arrived at Alexandria at 6.30 pm. yesterday from Boston with 175 tourists 173 board. This steamer was formerly know as the "Common wealth," of the Dominion Lane. She had a fiue run of 72 hours from Naples, her last port of call

SUEZ CANAL-On the 21st and 22nd inst. 31 vessels passed through the Canal, the amount received in dues being frs. 817,481.46. Is were British ships, 5 German, 3 Austrian, 2 French, 1 Norwegian, 1 Egyptian, 1 Italiau. The receipts from the 1st to 22nd inst. to- talled frs. 8,137,811.66.

THE TELEPHONE COMPANY OF EGYPT has now completed telephonic communication in thirty markazes between the police officers of the districts and the moudiriehs, as well as between the former and the omdehs of the different localities in each district or markaz. It is intended to extend the system gradually in the remaining moudiriehs of the country.

AN EXILE IN EGYPT.-In pursuance of a decision of the Central Criminal Court, Constan tinople, a further term of ten days has been granted to Iskender Shehkub, a fugitive, to appear before it. He is in Egypt, where he publishes seditious matter against the Imperial Government. If he fails to return to Turkey within the prescribed term, he will be tried in absentia, and his property will be confiscated.

div.head:
THE MAHMAL THEFT.
OFFICIAL VERSION.
div.p: In regard to the theft from the Mahmal's escort, we may state that the allegation in to-day's issue of a Cairo morning newspaper, that the case containing L.E. 8,000 in gold had after all been left in the Finance Ministry at Cairo, is quite untrue.
With regard to the theft, the following is the official version of the facts:

The money sent with the Mahmal was packed in twenty-two cases, three of which contained gold, the remainder silver coin. The packets were duly numbered and sealed at the Finance Ministry, and handed to over the "saraaf' of the Mahmal caravan, who counted them, found them correct, and gave the receipt for them. They were then taken down to Abbassieh under guard, and put in a waggon belonging to the baggage train of the Mahmal, which started overnight for Suez. In a carriage next to the waggon containing the money travelled an escort of two officers and 6 men. The waggon had been duly locked and sealed, as soon as the money had been placed in it at Abbas-sieh, and at each station at which the train stopped the escort got down and formed up on each side of it. On reaching Genife station, just before Suez, the escort found one of the seals broken, and investigation at Suez revealed the fact that a case containing L.E. 8,000 in gold had disappeared.

How the money was removed from the train is a mystery. There was no foot-board, by which an agile thief could have reached the waggon while in motion, and the weight of the case being over 50 okes appears to preclude the possibility of only one thief having been concerned. It is also remarkable that the thieves were able to select one of the three cases containing gold. Of course, this may be a case of fortune having favored the enterprise.

Investigations are being made by the police and the Parquet into the matter, and we hear that Morice Bey is actively engaged on the spot. The whole case presents very extraordinary features, and the theft appears to bo the work of at least two very ingenious criminals.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H the Khedive returned from his Ismailia estates to Koubbeh yesterday. His Highness will be at Abdeen to-morrow.
His Highness has been pleased to bestow the following grades on the undermentioned gentlemen :—
Mirmiran . Ibrahim Klhattab Pasha, notable of Cairo.

Abdel-Al Abd Errazek Bey, Cairo . Ahmed Eddai Bey, Cairo ; Mohamed Abounnasr Bey, Alexandria ; Ismail Hafez: Bey, Alexandria ; Hassan Bakry Bey. Sanieh Mohamed Tewfik Ettourgonman Bey. director of the "l'Ecole de la Mère T Abbas 1 ", Mohamed Hanafy El-Hennawi Bey, Cairo , Mahmoud Roustom Aids Boy, landowner . lieirgiiis Abd Echéhid Boy, Bebah; Mahmoud Yoasin Bey, Abonsir El-Mal.ik, Hassan Mohamed Essawi Bey, Mi'-ieh . Mourad Ecbéréi Bey, Minieh ; Matta Eddaïf Bey. Minieh , Dr. Abd el-Hamid Parid Bey, Zagazig ; Mahmoud Ahmed Youssef Ihwlallah Bey. Ras el-Khalig, (Qharbioh) ; Ibra-lim Moliamed Youssol Boy, Cherbine, (Qhar-web) , Mustapha Said Ahmad Ramadan Boy, Kesta, Gharbielij , Naguib Chakra Bey, Mah-iioud Hsssib Bey, of the reviow "Magallet-el-Wagallat" , Alslallah El-Gberiani Bey, Alex-oelria , Ibrahim Bey Hamdy, ïsmall Bey Lain b.
Salissah (with the title of Bey) : Bassili Mansour el-Gabalawi Bey, Cairo

div.head: ENGLISH CHURCH AT TANTAH.
div.p: The Church Council have issued an abstract of the accounts of the English Church at Tantah since the beginning of the movement there to 31st December, 1904. The local fund shows a credit balance of a little over £8, and the S.P.G.. fund of something like £16. The council, however, make an appeal for sub scriptions in aid of the local fund. The objects of the latter are (l) to cover the rent of Church House. (This the local com-munity in Tantah will meet, but extra help is asked for the land and building referred to in next item) ; (II) purchase of land on which to build a small Church House, the church to be on ground floor and chaplain's residence above it. Payment of rent will then cease and the whole of the money now going on item No. I will be available for No. Ill ; (III) subscrip-tion to S, P G (Society for the Propagation of the Gospel) to help their grant for chaplain's stipend.

What is principally wanted is land on which to build a Church House, and that, we believe, would cost from £120 and £150. Wo shall be glad to receive and acknowledge subscriptions for this deserving objeot, or they may be sent direct to Mr. F. Murrell Wright, hon. secretary and treasurer, English Church Fund, Tantah.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Heathfield," of the Prince line, from London, left Falmouth on Saturday last, with general cargo, &c , for Malta and Alex andria.
The S.S. "Grecian Prince," from Manchester, left Malta on Monday last and is due here on Friday, with passengers and general cargo.
The Khédivial S.S. "Mariout" will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port-Said on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina and Alexandritta.

div.head:
THE EMPRESS EUGENIE
ARRIVAL IN CAIRO.
div.p: The ex Empress Eugenie, travelling incognita as the Comtesse do Pierrefonds, arrived at Cairo last night, viA Port Said, and is staying at the Savoy Hotel.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught will start for Cairo as soon as possible after landing to morrow forenoon. A special train will be awaiting the Royal party on the quays.
The landing of the Royal party at the Arsenal wharf being private, the publie will not be admitted to the Arsenal yard.
T.R.H. will be met on their arrival at Cairo by the Earl of Cromer, the Ministers, and Mr. Vincent Corbet

div.head: THE CAIRO SEASON.
div.p: The latest "Pall Mall Gazette" to hand remarks :—

The Cairo season this year will present some exceptional features. Next week the Duke of Connaught will put in an appearance, on his way up to Khartoum, and will, doubtless, be reminded of the first time he was there — the day after Tel-el-Kebir. Lord Wolseley, who is cruising in Levantine waters, may not impossibly look in. There is a certain bridge he will hardly cross without reminiscence of the "Good morning" ho gave Hamley there. Hamley thought he had earned something more than that, and Lord Wolseley has learnt since what it feels like when the powers that be do not behave quite well to you.

Then, his Grace of Devonshire, and his neighbour at Newmarket, Sir Ernest Cassel, are due to arrive in Egypt in time to welcome the Inspector-General of the Army. Sir Ernest has "been there," before ; his Grace not quite so often. Monte Carlo has been mostly the limit of his search for sunshine. One can imagine him contemplating the Sphinx without any particular appreciation of its reason to be, and the Pyramids from a Whig's point of view of Pharaoh, tempered with a constitutional wonder that any fellow should have taken such a lot of trouble

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: We are authorised to contradict the statement made by a Cairo contemporary on Monday that the Royal Berkshire Regiment rod the 2nd Battalion of the Rifle Brigade are shortly leaving Egypt and will not be replaced ; nor is there any intention to further reduce the number of British troops in this country.

Wo may also state that the other statement of our confrère, that the barracks at Kaar-el-Nil, now occupied by the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, and those newly built it Abbassieh are to be vacated and made ' over to the Egyptian Army, is wholly devoid of foundation.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND PORT SAID. NOVEL SUGGESTION.
div.p: A well-known member of the German oolony at Alexandria sends us the following communication:—

There are a good many people, and I belong to them, who think that Port Said means a danger to the future of Alexandria. The new ' full gauge railway to Port Said and the various * harbour improvements planned there are so many blows dealt at the further development ' of our city. Alexandrians ought to bestir themselves and devise means bow to meet and possibly obviate the threatening danger. While still in time I venture to throw out an idea in his direction. Why not bring the Suez Capal ' to the doors of Alexandria By straightening, widening and deepening the Mahmoudioh Canal, ' continuing it across the Rosetta and Damietta branches of the Nile, and making it join the Suez Canal somewhere near Ismailia or at the Bitter Lakes, a second waterway for the shipping trade to and from the East could bo created, by which Alexandria ' would bo benefitted in the same way as Port Said now is by the Lesseps canal.

There ought to be no more technical difficulties concerning the execution of such an undertaking across cultivated country, than there were in the case of the Manchester ship canal or the canal that unites the Baltio and North seas.
In case of the existence of a monopoly in favour-of the 8uez Canal it ought not to be forgotten that after some 60 years the present ( Suez Canal becomes the property of the Egyptian State.

div.head: SLAVE DEALER SENTENCED.
div.p: A court-martial sitting at Abdeen barracks J has condemned the Bishareen Mohamed Hussein, found guilty of slave-dealing near the Red Sea coast, to seven years' hard labour.

It will be remembered that the accused and his brother wore recently captured by a patrol from Etbai, acting on information received, while taking a Sudanese girl called Hawn, whom Mohamed had bought, to sell to Hedjazi traders.
Hamed Hussein, the brother of the accused, has been acquitted.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR.
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H. R. H the Archduke Otto of Austria Alexandria for Marseilles to-day by the , North German Lloyd S.S. "Schleswig."
Prince Mirza Arfat Ed-Dawlah Khan has had to give up his proposed Nile trip and leaves Alexandria by the "Tchitchagoff for
General de Negrier arrived at Alexandria by the Messageries Maritimes steamer this morning, and after paying a visit to Cairo will go on to Abyssinia.

Dr. Thaddeus Count Bolesta Kozsiedrodzki, the new Austro-Hungarian Diplomatie Agent, arrived by the 7.20 p.m. express at Cairo on Monday night, accompanied by Coant Stadnicky. He will visit Alexandria next Saturday for the Austro-Hungarian charity ball.

The P & O. S.S. "Macedonia" (Capt C. D. Bennett, R.N.R.), which arrived at Port Said yesterday afternoon, brought one hundred and fifty-three passengers for Egypt, among the moat distinguished being the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Earl and Countess Dalbousie, Marchiness of Donegal, Lady and Miss G. Goret, Major the Hon. and Mrs. Bourke, General Sir J. Maxwell, the ex-Empress Eugenie, (Comtesse de Pierrelonds), Comte Primoli, and Comte Clary.

A large number of visitors who arrived by the "Macedonia" proceeded to the Savoy yesterday evening, amongst them the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, General Maxwell, Mr. George Faber, M.P., Lord and Lady Dal-housie, Mr. and Mrs. Maguire, etc. All these parties had reservod their suites beforehand and the Savoy was quite fall yesterday evening.
Sir Thomas Lipton is expected at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, to-day.

The Savoy Restaurant is fall up every evening, many residents being usually to be seen among the Savoy's visitors. Yesterday evening wo noticed the Archduke Otto and a party of 4, Mr. Birkenruth and a party of 8, Mr. Phillip and Baroness Reinlein and a party of 6, the Earl and Countess of Londesborough and party, including Mr. Vincent Corbett and Lord George Cholmondeley, Capt. the Hon. Stanley and party, including Col. and Mrs. J. K. Watson, Mr. Mac hell and Mr. Guest, the Master of Ellibank, etc.
Mr. Lawford, who has been representing the Egyptian Government at the St. Louis Exhibition, has returned to Cairo.

The following passengers left Shellal by the "Memnon" to-day -Mr. Brand, Mr. Alfred John, Mrs. Camisky, Miss Chance, Miss Dudgeon, Mrs. E. Cochrane, Miss Cochrane, Miss Booth, Mr. Tunbridge, Mrs. Stevens, Mr. and Mrs. L. S. Montague, Mme. Chanliagent.

div.head: MUNICIPAL DELEGATION.
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 24 janvier 1905 à 4 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Préseuts : MM. Fcnderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, K Strosa, Dr. G. Vole nain, membres, W. P. Chat away, administrateur, I. Sedky, secrétaire.

La Délégation prend note et décide de soumettre & la Commission, deux lettres de S. E. lo Ministre de l'Intérieur informant 1* qu'il approuve le budget de 1905, 3* qu'il se voit obligé de suspendre le règlement sur le* chiens et la rage, le Ministère ayant mis à l'étude un règlementqui devra s'appliquer i tout^l'Egyptc.

La Délégation fiait remarquer à oet égard qu'étant donné le* circonstanciés, U y aurait lieu d'insister pour permettre à la Municipalité d'appliquer à title provisoire son règlement jusqu'à oe que d'aatroa mesures générales interviennent.

Va la lettre de 8 JS. le Ministre des Finances relative à la question de l'agrandissement du pont route du Gabbari et demandant à la Municipalité de contribuer à cette dépense à raison de LE. 6,000 en y comprenant l'appoint des corporations intéressées telles que le Commerce d'exportation, les tramways, etc., la Délégation se référant à la oorrespuudanoe échangée dans le temps à oe sujet avec l'administration des chemins de for et de laquelle il résulte que la contribation demandée était de L.B. 4,000 au minimum, mais désirant participer dans la pins large mesure possiblo à ce travail d'ntilité publique, décide de proposer à la Corn, de fixer la contribution municipale à L.E. 2,500, oe qui ajouté aux LE. 1,500 promises par le commeroe d'exportation, et L.E. 1,000 promises par la Sté des tramways portera à LE. 5,000 la contribution de la ville à oe travail dont le ooût est évalué par loi chemins de fer à L.E. 17.000.

Va la lettre do la Cie de Ramleh tendant à oe qu'elle .oit autorisée à établir un butoir et une guérite au terminus de sa ligne, la Délégation estime que n'ayant reçu aucune réponse de la Cie en oe qui concerne 1a question du droit de contrôie que la ville désire appliquer dans l'intérêt du public, elle se voit obligée de ne donner aucune suite à la nouvelle demande de la Société.

la Délégation prend note et décide de soumettre à la Commission une lettre de S. R le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant qu'il ne voit pas d'objection à ce que la ville prenne possession pour la transformer en pare d'nne partie dn terrain de l'bfipital bordant la rue d'Allemagne.
La Délégation déoide de mettre en eradication les travaux de pavage en vieilles dalles de 8 rue* et ruéOee des quartiers d'Anfouohjr.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: Si le Gouvernement et les contribuables, excédés par le gaspillage qui se fait à la Municipalité, se décidaient enfin à remplacer le système actuel par on système pins pratique, d'où le fonctionnarisme serait exclu, il resterait pour le senrice de la ville un excédent de recettes d'au moins 50,000 lrvreo, actaellemmt consacrées à payer an innombrable p—onnel qui ne fait rien, ou qui fait des riens, ce qd «et la même chose. Supposons eooote que cette heureuse modification ait lieu demain, usa que la nouvelle administration garde en ses mains l'excédent ainsi obtenu sans jamais an tandis compte. Partout ailleurs il en ifsnltisail une explosion d'indignation publique. loi efadà peine si l'on daigne en parier. L'iaditttenoo pour tout oe qui touche à l'intérêt public est telle que les pires scandales n'arrivent pas à émouvoir la population.

Qu'on an juge. En 1890, la commission d'é-dilité oédait la plaça à la Municipalité en laissant à œlleci un reliquat da 80,000 livrée. Dette somme, au lieu de rentrer dans la eaiats communa, fut aooaparée par le comité daa exportateur», soi-disant pour être placée à intérêt ou profit da la ville. H y a quinze ans du cela et avec l'intérêt que rapporte l'argent en Egypte cette somme a pu être plus que doublée dans oe laps de tempe. Ce n'est dono plus 80.000 mais 60,000 livra* sa moins dont le comité des exportateurs a désormais à rendre compte.

Va-t-il se décider à restituer cette ou préférera-t-il verser un intérêt proportionné. JL* résistance qu'il a constamment opposée à chaque réclamation qui lui a été adressée à oe propos n'est pas faite pour calmer les inquiétudes : c'eut, eu effet, sur les instanoes réitérées de plusieurs membres de la Commission que le comité des exportateurs fut obligé dan« les commencements de s'inscrira pour 600 livres au budget idnnicipaL Cela continua pendant quelques année*. Plus tard, M. AchiUoponlo, ayant soulevé de nouveau la question des 30.000 livres, se heurta à un mauvais vouloir si manifeste qu'il crut de sa dignité de donner sa démission de conseiller.

Le 26 décembre 1908, M. Zouro fait remarquer que l'allocation de LE 600 ordinairement payée par le commeroe d'exportation ne figure pas au budget de 1904. Il en demande le motif. Cette allocation devrait, ajoute-t-il, être plus importante, car elle représente lee intérêts de la somme de L.B. 30,000 qui restait en caisse lors do la création de la Municipalité. La Municipalité dépense bien plus que le montant de cette allocation pour l'entretien da quartier de Minet-el-Bassal et il est jnate qu'elle profite du produit intégral dee fonds payés par les contribuables pour les travaux d'édilité.

On lui répond que, cette année, le commeroe d'exportation a fiait face à die grosses dépenses pour l'achat d'nne pompe automobile et de tuyaux ainsi que poor dss réparations A la pompe flottante. Les intérêts et pins ont été consacrés à ces frais ; s'il y a des intérêts disponibles ils seront à la disposition de la Municipalité.

N'est-ce pas exquis t On fait remarquer an détenteur illicite d'une somme que s'il ne veut pas la restituer il ait du moins à en servir lee intérêts au créancier et il répond que s'il lui reste quelque chose après avoir fiait ses petites fredaines, U y songera et l'affaire en est restée là.
Cette année, le comité des exportateur* s'est inscrit pour 800 livres, alors que la somme qu'il détient, capitalisée depuis 15 ans, doit représenter un intérêt supérieur à 3,000 livres.

Il serait temps, croyons-nous, de s'expliquer. Que le comité rende compte de sa gestion et fasse connaltre le montant actuel du capital qu'il s'est chargé lui-même d'exploiter. La situation actuelle peut d'autant moins s'éterniser que l'entretien des rues de Minet-el-Bsssal, auquel la dite somme était destinée, est tombée entièrement à la charge de la Municipalité, du jour où MM. les exportateurs s'en sont emparés, ne voulant ni entretenir les rues en question ni affecter à oet entretien les intérêt* du oapital qu'ils détiennent St que les producteurs de ooton avaient destinés à oet ussge.

Si oe Messieurs s'obstinent à garder le secret sur leurs bénéfices, fl y a .un moyen bien simple pour la Municipalité de le* contraindre à parler, c'est de cesser d'entretenir les ruos de Minehel-BassoL Comme elles servent à peu près exclusivement au commerce et principalement au commeroe d'exportetioo, celui-ci devra bien y pourvoir dans son propre intérêt. Et lorsque le comité réolamera à la Municipalité, oe sera au tour de oelle-ci do faire la sourde oreille. Malheureusement les membres du comité étant aussi membres de la Commission on se trouve en face de deux têtes sous un même bonnet C'est pour ce motif que oela a pu durer quinze ans et que dans 15 autres années la solution ne sera pas plus avancée.

Le comité des exportateurs ne s'est pas contenté de garder pour lai le magot, il s'est débarrassé du même coup de son lot de vieux employés et de vieux matériaux, dotant ainsi là Municipalité naissante du germe du fonctionnarisme qui l'étouffera.

div.head: Societe Khediviale de Geographie
div.p: L seance de lundi a été une deception pour ceux qui avaient r pundu & l'invita con lava l'espoir d'entendre la rout du voyage to M. Jueger dans l'Afrique Urioukule Alle mande, de la bouche ingine de l'explorateur. Appelé par w Wlogrammg d'urgence 4 Port
J. Jaeger di partir dans la matinee pour cette ville, laissait ses excuses et le manuscrit de la conférence entre les mains de la Suclele.

Lauditoire Tilito yui remplissait la sallo & on se contenter de la sinple lecture faite par M. Bircher, qui s'était donné la peine de trav duire on français la relation originale alleman. de une grande carte murale et des dessins, dresses par M. Bonola, servaient a illustrer les cummunications, que l'assemblée a ucout Avec We plus vat wteret. Eo etlot, M. Jaeger, quoiqu'il agisse de localités solumairement conus, & su donner laut de details et con venirur AUS a communication tant, diutérêt uouveau, que laudituire y a trouvé une compensation de la deception éprouvee et a salué La lecture de ses applaudissements.
Abbato Pachs présidait la réuniou, comme d'habitude.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURBE.
div.p: Le marché est terme et présente de l'anima tion.

la reprise s'accentue pour certaines valeurs: c'est ainsi que la Banyue Nationale atteint 25 15,16, la Beberu 50 34, la Daira 22 1/4, La Salt and Soda 11.9, la Sunigovich 9 15, 16 et A Dolta Light 143 8.
Par contre la baisse continue pour l'Agricole à 10 7 16, pour les Colton Mills À 7 et pour la Ramleb kuulway & 8 1 1.
Les Eaux du Caire réactionnent à 1115.
